      Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT
    <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c44">Comment 44<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c44">Comment 44<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Currently the lack of this feature is a major deterrent from using Chrome (or any other Chromium based browser) as the *default browser* on macOS. This also includes a large number of people who are using a new desktop device running macOS for the first time after being within the iOS ecosystem. It also makes Chromium based browsers unusable for a number of websites which requires multi-factor credentials and custom password generation rules provided by custom credential providers.<span class="line"><!---->Currently the lack of this feature is a major deterrent from using Chrome (or any other Chromium based browser) as the *default browser* on macOS. This also includes a large number of people who are using a new desktop device running macOS for the first time after being within the iOS ecosystem. It also makes Chromium based browsers unusable for a number of websites which requires multi-factor credentials and custom password generation rules provided by custom credential providers.<!----></span><br><br>While this feature is being considered, if users have already set a Chromium based browser as the default browser, following might help.<span class="line"><!---->While this feature is being considered, if users have already set a Chromium based browser as the default browser, following might help.<!----></span><br><br>- They can use a browser switcher (such as browserosaurus <span class="line"><!---->- They can use a browser switcher (such as browserosaurus <!----></span>https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus"><!---->https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus<!----></a> ) on macOS so they can continue to use the the auto-fill functionalities using Safari for pop-ups and applications that open web links while not changing the default browser. <span class="line"><!----> ) on macOS so they can continue to use the the auto-fill functionalities using Safari for pop-ups and applications that open web links while not changing the default browser. <!----></span><br><br>- Alternatively they can unset Chromium based browser as the default browser by switching to Safari as the default browser as described here: <span class="line"><!---->- Alternatively they can unset Chromium based browser as the default browser by switching to Safari as the default browser as described here: <!----></span>https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac"><!---->https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac<!----></a><br><br>I hope for this feature to be implemented soon so we all can enjoy the conveniences, extensibility and the user experience provided by Chromium browsers.<span class="line"><!---->I hope for this feature to be implemented soon so we all can enjoy the conveniences, extensibility and the user experience provided by Chromium browsers.<!----></span><br><br>--- <span class="line"><!---->--- <!----></span><br><br>Further on this, Chromium based browsers can also be credential providers to macOS, which means users are free to make the choice on where to store their passwords.<span class="line"><!---->Further on this, Chromium based browsers can also be credential providers to macOS, which means users are free to make the choice on where to store their passwords.<!----></span><br><br>Such an integration will allow Chromium browser credential stores to be used within the macOS system including Safari. This might also allow users to make the choice to move to a different credentials ecosystem in the emergence of a better alternative, which can be possibly provided through Chromium. Such ability to migrate would also drive up the demand for Chromium OS based devices as currently this acts as a major barrier for switching.<span class="line"><!---->Such an integration will allow Chromium browser credential stores to be used within the macOS system including Safari. This might also allow users to make the choice to move to a different credentials ecosystem in the emergence of a better alternative, which can be possibly provided through Chromium. Such ability to migrate would also drive up the demand for Chromium OS based devices as currently this acts as a major barrier for switching.<!----></span><br><br>https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices"><!---->https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        tl;dr: +1, ★'ed<span class="line"><!---->tl;dr: +1, ★'ed<!----></span><br><br>Having used an iPhone for a while, I used the native Keychain feature on it and was able to use Chrome on Windows/iPhone due to the fact that Windows has a chrome extension so that iCloud Keychain can work with it, and the fact that Chrome on iOS works with the native Keychain. After switching from Windows to MacOS, I was surprised that Chrome doesn't work with iCloud Keychain. The fact it doesn't is a very large reason I don't use Chrome as my main browser; I only use it for one website (which doesn't currently work on Safari because it's in a beta version). If this functionality was added, I could easily see myself switching to Chrome/Chromium based browsers again, or at least using one interchangeably with Safari.<span class="line"><!---->Having used an iPhone for a while, I used the native Keychain feature on it and was able to use Chrome on Windows/iPhone due to the fact that Windows has a chrome extension so that iCloud Keychain can work with it, and the fact that Chrome on iOS works with the native Keychain. After switching from Windows to MacOS, I was surprised that Chrome doesn't work with iCloud Keychain. The fact it doesn't is a very large reason I don't use Chrome as my main browser; I only use it for one website (which doesn't currently work on Safari because it's in a beta version). If this functionality was added, I could easily see myself switching to Chrome/Chromium based browsers again, or at least using one interchangeably with Safari.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        +1 and starred.<span class="line"><!---->+1 and starred.<!----></span><br><br>This is my biggest gripe with Chromium-based browsers. I cannot fathom how this feature has not yet been considered - it's a huge usability step-up for macOS users who either store their passwords in iCloud Keychain or a password manager like Strongbox and so many third party platforms have integrated the macOS password autofill at this point. I really hope this is picked up soon.<span class="line"><!---->This is my biggest gripe with Chromium-based browsers. I cannot fathom how this feature has not yet been considered - it's a huge usability step-up for macOS users who either store their passwords in iCloud Keychain or a password manager like Strongbox and so many third party platforms have integrated the macOS password autofill at this point. I really hope this is picked up soon.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I have been waiting for this integration for a long time now. Without support for MacOS Autofill, the use of Chromium based browsers is completely unrealistic on Mac. This is unfortunate because you might run into a site that isnt optimized for Safari and requres a Chromium browser for full functionality. Because i use iCloud Passwords and support for this feature is missing, it means i will stick to using Safari for the foreseeable future.<span class="line"><!---->I have been waiting for this integration for a long time now.         Just a heads up for any Strongbox users waiting on this. We have now got an AutoFill extension implementation for Chrome. You can find our extension on the Chrome Web Store. Early feedback indicates we have (very) basic functionality but there are many problematic sites that we'll need to work on.<span class="line"><!---->Just a heads up for any Strongbox users waiting on this. We have now got an AutoFill extension implementation for Chrome. You can find our extension on the Chrome Web Store. Early feedback indicates we have (very) basic functionality but there are many problematic sites that we'll need to work on.<!----></span><br><br>Just make sure that you have "Third Party AutoFill" enabled under Database Settings > AutoFill<span class="line"><!---->Just make sure that you have "Third Party AutoFill" enabled under Database Settings &gt; AutoFill<!----></span><br><br>It would still be amazing if Chrome/Firefox integrated fully with the System AutoFill but this might be a while coming by the looks of things.<span class="line"><!---->It would still be amazing if Chrome/Firefox integrated fully with the System AutoFill but this might be a while coming by the looks of things.<!----></span><br>Cheers,<span class="line"><!---->Cheers,<!----></span><br>-Mark<span class="line"><!---->-Mark<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      <style>

         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      <div class="select-container">

          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by supp...@strongboxsafe.com (Jan 23, 2021)

This allows users to use other password managers and integrate into third party apps and browsers, as long as those apps/browsers integrate with this system. Safari supports this already and Mozilla are working on integrating Firefox.<span class="line"><!---->Apple have made their Password AutoFill system available on MacOS with the release of Big Sur.           Comment 44<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c44">Comment 44<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      bhagy...@gmail.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/2849619457" title="bhagy...@gmail.com"><!---->bhagy...@gmail.com<!----></a>
      bhagy...@gmail.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->bhagy...@gmail.com<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT
    <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c44">Comment 44<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c44">Comment 44<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Currently the lack of this feature is a major deterrent from using Chrome (or any other Chromium based browser) as the *default browser* on macOS. This also includes a large number of people who are using a new desktop device running macOS for the first time after being within the iOS ecosystem. It also makes Chromium based browsers unusable for a number of websites which requires multi-factor credentials and custom password generation rules provided by custom credential providers.<span class="line"><!---->Currently the lack of this feature is a major deterrent from using Chrome (or any other Chromium based browser) as the *default browser* on macOS. This also includes a large number of people who are using a new desktop device running macOS for the first time after being within the iOS ecosystem. It also makes Chromium based browsers unusable for a number of websites which requires multi-factor credentials and custom password generation rules provided by custom credential providers.<!----></span><br><br>While this feature is being considered, if users have already set a Chromium based browser as the default browser, following might help.<span class="line"><!---->While this feature is being considered, if users have already set a Chromium based browser as the default browser, following might help.<!----></span><br><br>- They can use a browser switcher (such as browserosaurus <span class="line"><!---->- They can use a browser switcher (such as browserosaurus <!----></span>https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus"><!---->https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus<!----></a> ) on macOS so they can continue to use the the auto-fill functionalities using Safari for pop-ups and applications that open web links while not changing the default browser. <span class="line"><!----> ) on macOS so they can continue to use the the auto-fill functionalities using Safari for pop-ups and applications that open web links while not changing the default browser. <!----></span><br><br>- Alternatively they can unset Chromium based browser as the default browser by switching to Safari as the default browser as described here: <span class="line"><!---->- Alternatively they can unset Chromium based browser as the default browser by switching to Safari as the default browser as described here: <!----></span>https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac"><!---->https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac<!----></a><br><br>I hope for this feature to be implemented soon so we all can enjoy the conveniences, extensibility and the user experience provided by Chromium browsers.<span class="line"><!---->I hope for this feature to be implemented soon so we all can enjoy the conveniences, extensibility and the user experience provided by Chromium browsers.<!----></span><br><br>--- <span class="line"><!---->--- <!----></span><br><br>Further on this, Chromium based browsers can also be credential providers to macOS, which means users are free to make the choice on where to store their passwords.<span class="line"><!---->Further on this, Chromium based browsers can also be credential providers to macOS, which means users are free to make the choice on where to store their passwords.<!----></span><br><br>Such an integration will allow Chromium browser credential stores to be used within the macOS system including Safari. This might also allow users to make the choice to move to a different credentials ecosystem in the emergence of a better alternative, which can be possibly provided through Chromium. Such ability to migrate would also drive up the demand for Chromium OS based devices as currently this acts as a major barrier for switching.<span class="line"><!---->Such an integration will allow Chromium browser credential stores to be used within the macOS system including Safari. This might also allow users to make the choice to move to a different credentials ecosystem in the emergence of a better alternative, which can be possibly provided through Chromium. Such ability to migrate would also drive up the demand for Chromium OS based devices as currently this acts as a major barrier for switching.<!----></span><br><br>https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices"><!---->https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        As long as chrome doesn’t use this integration, I will not use chrome. This is the type of vendor lock-in I don’t want and therefore don’t use chrome. If you do create this option to be able to use another password manager I will reconsider using chrome again.<span class="line"><!---->As long as chrome doesn’t use this integration, I will not use chrome. This is the type of vendor lock-in I don’t want and therefore don’t use chrome. If you do create this option to be able to use another password manager I will reconsider using chrome again.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        tl;dr: +1, ★'ed<span class="line"><!---->tl;dr: +1, ★'ed<!----></span><br><br>Having used an iPhone for a while, I used the native Keychain feature on it and was able to use Chrome on Windows/iPhone due to the fact that Windows has a chrome extension so that iCloud Keychain can work with it, and the fact that Chrome on iOS works with the native Keychain. After switching from Windows to MacOS, I was surprised that Chrome doesn't work with iCloud Keychain. The fact it doesn't is a very large reason I don't use Chrome as my main browser; I only use it for one website (which doesn't currently work on Safari because it's in a beta version). If this functionality was added, I could easily see myself switching to Chrome/Chromium based browsers again, or at least using one interchangeably with Safari.<span class="line"><!---->Having used an iPhone for a while, I used the native Keychain feature on it and was able to use Chrome on Windows/iPhone due to the fact that Windows has a chrome extension so that iCloud Keychain can work with it, and the fact that Chrome on iOS works with the native Keychain. After switching from Windows to MacOS, I was surprised that Chrome doesn't work with iCloud Keychain. The fact it doesn't is a very large reason I don't use Chrome as my main browser; I only use it for one website (which doesn't currently work on Safari because it's in a beta version). If this functionality was added, I could easily see myself switching to Chrome/Chromium based browsers again, or at least using one interchangeably with Safari.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        +1 and starred.<span class="line"><!---->+1 and starred.<!----></span><br><br>This is my biggest gripe with Chromium-based browsers. I cannot fathom how this feature has not yet been considered - it's a huge usability step-up for macOS users who either store their passwords in iCloud Keychain or a password manager like Strongbox and so many third party platforms have integrated the macOS password autofill at this point. I really hope this is picked up soon.<span class="line"><!---->This is my biggest gripe with Chromium-based browsers. I cannot fathom how this feature has not yet been considered - it's a huge usability step-up for macOS users who either store their passwords in iCloud Keychain or a password manager like Strongbox and so many third party platforms have integrated the macOS password autofill at this point. I really hope this is picked up soon.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Just a heads up for any Strongbox users waiting on this. We have now got an AutoFill extension implementation for Chrome. You can find our extension on the Chrome Web Store. Early feedback indicates we have (very) basic functionality but there are many problematic sites that we'll need to work on.<span class="line"><!---->Just a heads up for any Strongbox users waiting on this. We have now got an AutoFill extension implementation for Chrome. You can find our extension on the Chrome Web Store. Early feedback indicates we have (very) basic functionality but there are many problematic sites that we'll need to work on.<!----></span><br><br>Just make sure that you have "Third Party AutoFill" enabled under Database Settings > AutoFill<span class="line"><!---->Just make sure that you have "Third Party AutoFill" enabled under Database Settings &gt; AutoFill<!----></span><br><br>It would still be amazing if Chrome/Firefox integrated fully with the System AutoFill but this might be a while coming by the looks of things.<span class="line"><!---->It would still be amazing if Chrome/Firefox integrated fully with the System AutoFill but this might be a while coming by the looks of things.<!----></span><br>Cheers,<span class="line"><!---->Cheers,<!----></span><br>-Mark<span class="line"><!---->-Mark<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

      UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 11_1_0) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/88.0.4324.96 Safari/537.36<span class="line"><!---->UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 11_1_0) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/88.0.4324.96 Safari/537.36<!----></span><br><br>Steps to reproduce the problem:<span class="line"><!---->Steps to reproduce the problem:<!----></span><br>Apple have made their Password AutoFill system available on MacOS with the release of Big Sur. This allows users to use other password managers and integrate into third party apps and browsers, as long as those apps/browsers integrate with this system. Safari supports this already and Mozilla are working on integrating Firefox.<span class="line"><!---->Apple have made their Password AutoFill system available on MacOS with the release of Big Sur. This allows users to use other password managers and integrate into third party apps and browsers, as long as those apps/browsers integrate with this system. Safari supports this already and Mozilla are working on integrating Firefox.<!----></span><br><br>https://developer.apple.com/documentation/security/password_autofill<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/security/password_autofill"><!---->https://developer.apple.com/documentation/security/password_autofill<!----></a><br><br>At the moment Chrome does not integrate with this system. <span class="line"><!---->At the moment Chrome does not integrate with this system. <!----></span><br><br>Are there plans to do so? This provides a secure way to transfer Username/Passwords from any Password Manager that supports it. <span class="line"><!---->Are there plans to do so? This provides a secure way to transfer Username/Passwords from any Password Manager that supports it. <!----></span><br><br>I am the main developer of Strongbox, an independent Password Manager for iOS and Mac supporting KeePass and Password Safe.<span class="line"><!---->I am the main developer of Strongbox, an independent Password Manager for iOS and Mac supporting KeePass and Password Safe.<!----></span><br><br>What is the expected behavior?<span class="line"><!---->What is the expected behavior?<!----></span><br><br>What went wrong?<span class="line"><!---->What went wrong?<!----></span><br>As above, this is a request for integration with the Apple Password AutoFill system on Mac.<span class="line"><!---->As above, this is a request for integration with the Apple Password AutoFill system on Mac.<!----></span><br><br>Did this work before? N/A <span class="line"><!---->Did this work before? N/A <!----></span><br><br>Chrome version: 88.0.4324.96  Channel: stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome version: 88.0.4324.96  Channel: stable<!----></span><br>OS Version: OS X 11.1.0<span class="line"><!---->OS Version: OS X 11.1.0<!----></span><br>Flash Version: <span class="line"><!---->Flash Version: <!----></span><br><br>Apologies if this isn't the right forum, would appreciate any pointers to the correct place to raise this.<span class="line"><!---->Apologies if this isn't the right forum, would appreciate any pointers to the correct place to raise this.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by

      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c44">Comment 44<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Currently the lack of this feature is a major deterrent from using Chrome (or any other Chromium based browser) as the *default browser* on macOS. This also includes a large number of people who are using a new desktop device running macOS for the first time after being within the iOS ecosystem. It also makes Chromium based browsers unusable for a number of websites which requires multi-factor credentials and custom password generation rules provided by custom credential providers.<span class="line"><!---->Currently the lack of this feature is a major deterrent from using Chrome (or any other Chromium based browser) as the *default browser* on macOS. This also includes a large number of people who are using a new desktop device running macOS for the first time after being within the iOS ecosystem. It also makes Chromium based browsers unusable for a number of websites which requires multi-factor credentials and custom password generation rules provided by custom credential providers.<!----></span><br><br>While this feature is being considered, if users have already set a Chromium based browser as the default browser, following might help.<span class="line"><!---->While this feature is being considered, if users have already set a Chromium based browser as the default browser, following might help.<!----></span><br><br>- They can use a browser switcher (such as browserosaurus <span class="line"><!---->- They can use a browser switcher (such as browserosaurus <!----></span>https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus"><!---->https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus<!----></a> ) on macOS so they can continue to use the the auto-fill functionalities using Safari for pop-ups and applications that open web links while not changing the default browser. <span class="line"><!----> ) on macOS so they can continue to use the the auto-fill functionalities using Safari for pop-ups and applications that open web links while not changing the default browser. <!----></span><br><br>- Alternatively they can unset Chromium based browser as the default browser by switching to Safari as the default browser as described here: <span class="line"><!---->- Alternatively they can unset Chromium based browser as the default browser by switching to Safari as the default browser as described here: <!----></span>https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac"><!---->https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac<!----></a><br><br>I hope for this feature to be implemented soon so we all can enjoy the conveniences, extensibility and the user experience provided by Chromium browsers.<span class="line"><!---->I hope for this feature to be implemented soon so we all can enjoy the conveniences, extensibility and the user experience provided by Chromium browsers.<!----></span><br><br>--- <span class="line"><!---->--- <!----></span><br><br>Further on this, Chromium based browsers can also be credential providers to macOS, which means users are free to make the choice on where to store their passwords.<span class="line"><!---->Further on this, Chromium based browsers can also be credential providers to macOS, which means users are free to make the choice on where to store their passwords.<!----></span><br><br>Such an integration will allow Chromium browser credential stores to be used within the macOS system including Safari. This might also allow users to make the choice to move to a different credentials ecosystem in the emergence of a better alternative, which can be possibly provided through Chromium. Such ability to migrate would also drive up the demand for Chromium OS based devices as currently this acts as a major barrier for switching.<span class="line"><!---->Such an integration will allow Chromium browser credential stores to be used within the macOS system including Safari. This might also allow users to make the choice to move to a different credentials ecosystem in the emergence of a better alternative, which can be possibly provided through Chromium. Such ability to migrate would also drive up the demand for Chromium OS based devices as currently this acts as a major barrier for switching.<!----></span><br><br>https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices"><!---->https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        tl;dr: +1, ★'ed<span class="line"><!---->tl;dr: +1, ★'ed<!----></span><br><br>Having used an iPhone for a while, I used the native Keychain feature on it and was able to use Chrome on Windows/iPhone due to the fact that Windows has a chrome extension so that iCloud Keychain can work with it, and the fact that Chrome on iOS works with the native Keychain. After switching from Windows to MacOS, I was surprised that Chrome doesn't work with iCloud Keychain. The fact it doesn't is a very large reason I don't use Chrome as my main browser; I only use it for one website (which doesn't currently work on Safari because it's in a beta version). If this functionality was added, I could easily see myself switching to Chrome/Chromium based browsers again, or at least using one interchangeably with Safari.<span class="line"><!---->Having used an iPhone for a while, I used the native Keychain feature on it and was able to use Chrome on Windows/iPhone due to the fact that Windows has a chrome extension so that iCloud Keychain can work with it, and the fact that Chrome on iOS works with the native Keychain. After switching from Windows to MacOS, I was surprised that Chrome doesn't work with iCloud Keychain. The fact it doesn't is a very large reason I don't use Chrome as my main browser; I only use it for one website (which doesn't currently work on Safari because it's in a beta version). If this functionality was added, I could easily see myself switching to Chrome/Chromium based browsers again, or at least using one interchangeably with Safari.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>
    
      
    <mr-comment headinglevel="2"></mr-comment>

        +1 and starred.<span class="line"><!---->+1 and starred.<!----></span><br><br>This is my biggest gripe with Chromium-based browsers. I cannot fathom how this feature has not yet been considered - it's a huge usability step-up for macOS users who either store their passwords in iCloud Keychain or a password manager like Strongbox and so many third party platforms have integrated the macOS password autofill at this point. I really hope this is picked up soon.<span class="line"><!---->This is my biggest gripe with Chromium-based browsers. I cannot fathom how this feature has not yet been considered - it's a huge usability step-up for macOS users who either store their passwords in iCloud Keychain or a password manager like Strongbox and so many third party platforms have integrated the macOS password autofill at this point. I really hope this is picked up soon.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I have been waiting for this integration for a long time now. Without support for MacOS Autofill, the use of Chromium based browsers is completely unrealistic on Mac. This is unfortunate because you might run into a site that isnt optimized for Safari and requres a Chromium browser for full functionality. Because i use iCloud Passwords and support for this feature is missing, it means i will stick to using Safari for the foreseeable future.<span class="line"><!---->I have been waiting for this integration for a long time now. Without support for MacOS Autofill, the use of Chromium based browsers is completely unrealistic on Mac. This is unfortunate because you might run into a site that isnt optimized for Safari and requres a Chromium browser for full functionality. Because i use iCloud Passwords and support for this feature is missing, it means i will stick to using Safari for the foreseeable future.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>

        Just a heads up for any Strongbox users waiting on this. We have now got an AutoFill extension implementation for Chrome. You can find our extension on the Chrome Web Store. Early feedback indicates we have (very) basic functionality but there are many problematic sites that we'll need to work on.<span class="line"><!---->Just a heads up for any Strongbox users waiting on this. We have now got an AutoFill extension implementation for Chrome. You can find our extension on the Chrome Web Store. Early feedback indicates we have (very) basic functionality but there are many problematic sites that we'll need to work on.<!----></span><br><br>Just make sure that you have "Third Party AutoFill" enabled under Database Settings > AutoFill<span class="line"><!---->Just make sure that you have "Third Party AutoFill" enabled under Database Settings &gt; AutoFill<!----></span><br><br>It would still be amazing if Chrome/Firefox integrated fully with the System AutoFill but this might be a while coming by the looks of things.<span class="line"><!---->It would still be amazing if Chrome/Firefox integrated fully with the System AutoFill but this might be a while coming by the looks of things.<!----></span><br>Cheers,<span class="line"><!---->Cheers,<!----></span><br>-Mark<span class="line"><!---->-Mark<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

This allows users to use other password managers and integrate into third party apps and browsers, as long as those apps/browsers integrate with this system. Safari supports this already and Mozilla are working on integrating Firefox.<span class="line"><!---->Apple have made their Password AutoFill system available on MacOS with the release of Big Sur. This allows users to use other password managers and integrate into third party apps and browsers, as long as those apps/browsers integrate with this system. Safari supports this already and Mozilla are working on integrating Firefox.<!----></span><br><br>https://developer.apple.com/documentation/security/password_autofill<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/security/password_autofill"><!---->https://developer.apple.com/documentation/security/password_autofill<!----></a><br><br>At the moment Chrome does not integrate with this system. <span class="line"><!---->At the moment Chrome does not integrate with this system. <!----></span><br><br>Are there plans to do so? This provides a secure way to transfer Username/Passwords from any Password Manager that supports it. <span class="line"><!---->Are there plans to do so?           Comment 44<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c44">Comment 44<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      bhagy...@gmail.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/2849619457" title="bhagy...@gmail.com"><!---->bhagy...@gmail.com<!----></a>
      bhagy...@gmail.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->bhagy...@gmail.com<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT
    <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c44">Comment 44<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c44">Comment 44<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Currently the lack of this feature is a major deterrent from using Chrome (or any other Chromium based browser) as the *default browser* on macOS. This also includes a large number of people who are using a new desktop device running macOS for the first time after being within the iOS ecosystem. It also makes Chromium based browsers unusable for a number of websites which requires multi-factor credentials and custom password generation rules provided by custom credential providers.<span class="line"><!---->Currently the lack of this feature is a major deterrent from using Chrome (or any other Chromium based browser) as the *default browser* on macOS. This also includes a large number of people who are using a new desktop device running macOS for the first time after being within the iOS ecosystem. It also makes Chromium based browsers unusable for a number of websites which requires multi-factor credentials and custom password generation rules provided by custom credential providers.<!----></span><br><br>While this feature is being considered, if users have already set a Chromium based browser as the default browser, following might help.<span class="line"><!---->While this feature is being considered, if users have already set a Chromium based browser as the default browser, following might help.<!----></span><br><br>- They can use a browser switcher (such as browserosaurus <span class="line"><!---->- They can use a browser switcher (such as browserosaurus <!----></span>https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus"><!---->https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus<!----></a> ) on macOS so they can continue to use the the auto-fill functionalities using Safari for pop-ups and applications that open web links while not changing the default browser. <span class="line"><!----> ) on macOS so they can continue to use the the auto-fill functionalities using Safari for pop-ups and applications that open web links while not changing the default browser. <!----></span><br><br>- Alternatively they can unset Chromium based browser as the default browser by switching to Safari as the default browser as described here: <span class="line"><!---->- Alternatively they can unset Chromium based browser as the default browser by switching to Safari as the default browser as described here: <!----></span>https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac"><!---->https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac<!----></a><br><br>I hope for this feature to be implemented soon so we all can enjoy the conveniences, extensibility and the user experience provided by Chromium browsers.<span class="line"><!---->I hope for this feature to be implemented soon so we all can enjoy the conveniences, extensibility and the user experience provided by Chromium browsers.<!----></span><br><br>--- <span class="line"><!---->--- <!----></span><br><br>Further on this, Chromium based browsers can also be credential providers to macOS, which means users are free to make the choice on where to store their passwords.<span class="line"><!---->Further on this, Chromium based browsers can also be credential providers to macOS, which means users are free to make the choice on where to store their passwords.<!----></span><br><br>Such an integration will allow Chromium browser credential stores to be used within the macOS system including Safari. This might also allow users to make the choice to move to a different credentials ecosystem in the emergence of a better alternative, which can be possibly provided through Chromium. Such ability to migrate would also drive up the demand for Chromium OS based devices as currently this acts as a major barrier for switching.<span class="line"><!---->Such an integration will allow Chromium browser credential stores to be used within the macOS system including Safari. This might also allow users to make the choice to move to a different credentials ecosystem in the emergence of a better alternative, which can be possibly provided through Chromium. Such ability to migrate would also drive up the demand for Chromium OS based devices as currently this acts as a major barrier for switching.<!----></span><br><br>https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices"><!---->https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

          Comment 57<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c57">Comment 57<!----></a>

          
        by

        tl;dr: +1, ★'ed<span class="line"><!---->tl;dr: +1, ★'ed<!----></span><br><br>Having used an iPhone for a while, I used the native Keychain feature on it and was able to use Chrome on Windows/iPhone due to the fact that Windows has a chrome extension so that iCloud Keychain can work with it, and the fact that Chrome on iOS works with the native Keychain. After switching from Windows to MacOS, I was surprised that Chrome doesn't work with iCloud Keychain. The fact it doesn't is a very large reason I don't use Chrome as my main browser; I only use it for one website (which doesn't currently work on Safari because it's in a beta version). If this functionality was added, I could easily see myself switching to Chrome/Chromium based browsers again, or at least using one interchangeably with Safari.<span class="line"><!---->Having used an iPhone for a while, I used the native Keychain feature on it and was able to use Chrome on Windows/iPhone due to the fact that Windows has a chrome extension so that iCloud Keychain can work with it, and the fact that Chrome on iOS works with the native Keychain. After switching from Windows to MacOS, I was surprised that Chrome doesn't work with iCloud Keychain. The fact it doesn't is a very large reason I don't use Chrome as my main browser; I only use it for one website (which doesn't currently work on Safari because it's in a beta version). If this functionality was added, I could easily see myself switching to Chrome/Chromium based browsers again, or at least using one interchangeably with Safari.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        +1 and starred.<span class="line"><!---->+1 and starred.<!----></span><br><br>This is my biggest gripe with Chromium-based browsers. I cannot fathom how this feature has not yet been considered - it's a huge usability step-up for macOS users who either store their passwords in iCloud Keychain or a password manager like Strongbox and so many third party platforms have integrated the macOS password autofill at this point. I really hope this is picked up soon.<span class="line"><!---->This is my biggest gripe with Chromium-based browsers. I cannot fathom how this feature has not yet been considered - it's a huge usability step-up for macOS users who either store their passwords in iCloud Keychain or a password manager like Strongbox and so many third party platforms have integrated the macOS password autofill at this point. I really hope this is picked up soon.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Just a heads up for any Strongbox users waiting on this. We have now got an AutoFill extension implementation for Chrome. You can find our extension on the Chrome Web Store. Early feedback indicates we have (very) basic functionality but there are many problematic sites that we'll need to work on.<span class="line"><!---->Just a heads up for any Strongbox users waiting on this. We have now got an AutoFill extension implementation for Chrome. You can find our extension on the Chrome Web Store. Early feedback indicates we have (very) basic functionality but there are many problematic sites that we'll need to work on.<!----></span><br><br>Just make sure that you have "Third Party AutoFill" enabled under Database Settings > AutoFill<span class="line"><!---->Just make sure that you have "Third Party AutoFill" enabled under Database Settings &gt; AutoFill<!----></span><br><br>It would still be amazing if Chrome/Firefox integrated fully with the System AutoFill but this might be a while coming by the looks of things.<span class="line"><!---->It would still be amazing if Chrome/Firefox integrated fully with the System AutoFill but this might be a while coming by the looks of things.<!----></span><br>Cheers,<span class="line"><!---->Cheers,<!----></span><br>-Mark<span class="line"><!---->-Mark<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 11_1_0) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/88.0.4324.96 Safari/537.36<span class="line"><!---->UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 11_1_0) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/88.0.4324.96 Safari/537.36<!----></span><br><br>Steps to reproduce the problem:<span class="line"><!---->Steps to reproduce the problem:<!----></span><br>Apple have made their Password AutoFill system available on MacOS with the release of Big Sur. This allows users to use other password managers and integrate into third party apps and browsers, as long as those apps/browsers integrate with this system. Safari supports this already and Mozilla are working on integrating Firefox.<span class="line"><!---->Apple have made their Password AutoFill system available on MacOS with the release of Big Sur. This allows users to use other password managers and integrate into third party apps and browsers, as long as those apps/browsers integrate with this system. Safari supports this already and Mozilla are working on integrating Firefox.<!----></span><br><br>https://developer.apple.com/documentation/security/password_autofill<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/security/password_autofill"><!---->https://developer.apple.com/documentation/security/password_autofill<!----></a><br><br>At the moment Chrome does not integrate with this system. <span class="line"><!---->At the moment Chrome does not integrate with this system. <!----></span><br><br>Are there plans to do so? This provides a secure way to transfer Username/Passwords from any Password Manager that supports it. <span class="line"><!---->Are there plans to do so? This provides a secure way to transfer Username/Passwords from any Password Manager that supports it. <!----></span><br><br>I am the main developer of Strongbox, an independent Password Manager for iOS and Mac supporting KeePass and Password Safe.<span class="line"><!---->I am the main developer of Strongbox, an independent Password Manager for iOS and Mac supporting KeePass and Password Safe.<!----></span><br><br>What is the expected behavior?<span class="line"><!---->What is the expected behavior?<!----></span><br><br>What went wrong?<span class="line"><!---->What went wrong?<!----></span><br>As above, this is a request for integration with the Apple Password AutoFill system on Mac.<span class="line"><!---->As above, this is a request for integration with the Apple Password AutoFill system on Mac.<!----></span><br><br>Did this work before? N/A <span class="line"><!---->Did this work before? N/A <!----></span><br><br>Chrome version: 88.0.4324.96  Channel: stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome version: 88.0.4324.96  Channel: stable<!----></span><br>OS Version: OS X 11.1.0<span class="line"><!---->OS Version: OS X 11.1.0<!----></span><br>Flash Version: <span class="line"><!---->Flash Version: <!----></span><br><br>Apologies if this isn't the right forum, would appreciate any pointers to the correct place to raise this.<span class="line"><!---->Apologies if this isn't the right forum, would appreciate any pointers to the correct place to raise this.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 44<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c44">Comment 44<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      bhagy...@gmail.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/2849619457" title="bhagy...@gmail.com"><!---->bhagy...@gmail.com<!----></a>
      bhagy...@gmail.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->bhagy...@gmail.com<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT
    <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c44">Comment 44<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c44">Comment 44<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Currently the lack of this feature is a major deterrent from using Chrome (or any other Chromium based browser) as the *default browser* on macOS. This also includes a large number of people who are using a new desktop device running macOS for the first time after being within the iOS ecosystem. It also makes Chromium based browsers unusable for a number of websites which requires multi-factor credentials and custom password generation rules provided by custom credential providers.<span class="line"><!---->Currently the lack of this feature is a major deterrent from using Chrome (or any other Chromium based browser) as the *default browser* on macOS. This also includes a large number of people who are using a new desktop device running macOS for the first time after being within the iOS ecosystem. It also makes Chromium based browsers unusable for a number of websites which requires multi-factor credentials and custom password generation rules provided by custom credential providers.<!----></span><br><br>While this feature is being considered, if users have already set a Chromium based browser as the default browser, following might help.<span class="line"><!---->While this feature is being considered, if users have already set a Chromium based browser as the default browser, following might help.<!----></span><br><br>- They can use a browser switcher (such as browserosaurus <span class="line"><!---->- They can use a browser switcher (such as browserosaurus <!----></span>https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus"><!---->https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus<!----></a> ) on macOS so they can continue to use the the auto-fill functionalities using Safari for pop-ups and applications that open web links while not changing the default browser. <span class="line"><!----> ) on macOS so they can continue to use the the auto-fill functionalities using Safari for pop-ups and applications that open web links while not changing the default browser. <!----></span><br><br>- Alternatively they can unset Chromium based browser as the default browser by switching to Safari as the default browser as described here: <span class="line"><!---->- Alternatively they can unset Chromium based browser as the default browser by switching to Safari as the default browser as described here: <!----></span>https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac"><!---->https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac<!----></a><br><br>I hope for this feature to be implemented soon so we all can enjoy the conveniences, extensibility and the user experience provided by Chromium browsers.<span class="line"><!---->I hope for this feature to be implemented soon so we all can enjoy the conveniences, extensibility and the user experience provided by Chromium browsers.<!----></span><br><br>--- <span class="line"><!---->--- <!----></span><br><br>Further on this, Chromium based browsers can also be credential providers to macOS, which means users are free to make the choice on where to store their passwords.<span class="line"><!---->Further on this, Chromium based browsers can also be credential providers to macOS, which means users are free to make the choice on where to store their passwords.<!----></span><br><br>Such an integration will allow Chromium browser credential stores to be used within the macOS system including Safari. This might also allow users to make the choice to move to a different credentials ecosystem in the emergence of a better alternative, which can be possibly provided through Chromium. Such ability to migrate would also drive up the demand for Chromium OS based devices as currently this acts as a major barrier for switching.<span class="line"><!---->Such an integration will allow Chromium browser credential stores to be used within the macOS system including Safari. This might also allow users to make the choice to move to a different credentials ecosystem in the emergence of a better alternative, which can be possibly provided through Chromium. Such ability to migrate would also drive up the demand for Chromium OS based devices as currently this acts as a major barrier for switching.<!----></span><br><br>https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices"><!---->https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        As long as chrome doesn’t use this integration, I will not use chrome. This is the type of vendor lock-in I don’t want and therefore don’t use chrome.         tl;dr: +1, ★'ed<span class="line"><!---->tl;dr: +1, ★'ed<!----></span><br><br>Having used an iPhone for a while, I used the native Keychain feature on it and was able to use Chrome on Windows/iPhone due to the fact that Windows has a chrome extension so that iCloud Keychain can work with it, and the fact that Chrome on iOS works with the native Keychain. After switching from Windows to MacOS, I was surprised that Chrome doesn't work with iCloud Keychain. The fact it doesn't is a very large reason I don't use Chrome as my main browser; I only use it for one website (which doesn't currently work on Safari because it's in a beta version). If this functionality was added, I could easily see myself switching to Chrome/Chromium based browsers again, or at least using one interchangeably with Safari.<span class="line"><!---->Having used an iPhone for a while, I used the native Keychain feature on it and was able to use Chrome on Windows/iPhone due to the fact that Windows has a chrome extension so that iCloud Keychain can work with it, and the fact that Chrome on iOS works with the native Keychain. After switching from Windows to MacOS, I was surprised that Chrome doesn't work with iCloud Keychain. The fact it doesn't is a very large reason I don't use Chrome as my main browser; I only use it for one website (which doesn't currently work on Safari because it's in a beta version). If this functionality was added, I could easily see myself switching to Chrome/Chromium based browsers again, or at least using one interchangeably with Safari.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        +1 and starred.<span class="line"><!---->+1 and starred.<!----></span><br><br>This is my biggest gripe with Chromium-based browsers. I cannot fathom how this feature has not yet been considered - it's a huge usability step-up for macOS users who either store their passwords in iCloud Keychain or a password manager like Strongbox and so many third party platforms have integrated the macOS password autofill at this point. I really hope this is picked up soon.<span class="line"><!---->This is my biggest gripe with Chromium-based browsers. I cannot fathom how this feature has not yet been considered - it's a huge usability step-up for macOS users who either store their passwords in iCloud Keychain or a password manager like Strongbox and so many third party platforms have integrated the macOS password autofill at this point. I really hope this is picked up soon.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

However, if you can pull in more people to use google products, Chrome in this case, it is the first step in bringing over more people to the google ecosystem.<span class="line"><!---->This is a feature that is essential to Apple users.         Just a heads up for any Strongbox users waiting on this. We have now got an AutoFill extension implementation for Chrome. You can find our extension on the Chrome Web Store. Early feedback indicates we have (very) basic functionality but there are many problematic sites that we'll need to work on.<span class="line"><!---->Just a heads up for any Strongbox users waiting on this. We have now got an AutoFill extension implementation for Chrome. You can find our extension on the Chrome Web Store. Early feedback indicates we have (very) basic functionality but there are many problematic sites that we'll need to work on.<!----></span><br><br>Just make sure that you have "Third Party AutoFill" enabled under Database Settings > AutoFill<span class="line"><!---->Just make sure that you have "Third Party AutoFill" enabled under Database Settings &gt; AutoFill<!----></span><br><br>It would still be amazing if Chrome/Firefox integrated fully with the System AutoFill but this might be a while coming by the looks of things.<span class="line"><!---->It would still be amazing if Chrome/Firefox integrated fully with the System AutoFill but this might be a while coming by the looks of things.<!----></span><br>Cheers,<span class="line"><!---->Cheers,<!----></span><br>-Mark<span class="line"><!---->-Mark<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

This allows users to use other password managers and integrate into third party apps and browsers, as long as those apps/browsers integrate with this system. Safari supports this already and Mozilla are working on integrating Firefox.<span class="line"><!---->Apple have made their Password AutoFill system available on MacOS with the release of Big Sur.         <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>

      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c44">Comment 44<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Mar 30, 2022, 5:07 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Currently the lack of this feature is a major deterrent from using Chrome (or any other Chromium based browser) as the *default browser* on macOS. This also includes a large number of people who are using a new desktop device running macOS for the first time after being within the iOS ecosystem. It also makes Chromium based browsers unusable for a number of websites which requires multi-factor credentials and custom password generation rules provided by custom credential providers.<span class="line"><!---->Currently the lack of this feature is a major deterrent from using Chrome (or any other Chromium based browser) as the *default browser* on macOS. This also includes a large number of people who are using a new desktop device running macOS for the first time after being within the iOS ecosystem. It also makes Chromium based browsers unusable for a number of websites which requires multi-factor credentials and custom password generation rules provided by custom credential providers.<!----></span><br><br>While this feature is being considered, if users have already set a Chromium based browser as the default browser, following might help.<span class="line"><!---->While this feature is being considered, if users have already set a Chromium based browser as the default browser, following might help.<!----></span><br><br>- They can use a browser switcher (such as browserosaurus <span class="line"><!---->- They can use a browser switcher (such as browserosaurus <!----></span>https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus"><!---->https://github.com/will-stone/browserosaurus<!----></a> ) on macOS so they can continue to use the the auto-fill functionalities using Safari for pop-ups and applications that open web links while not changing the default browser. <span class="line"><!----> ) on macOS so they can continue to use the the auto-fill functionalities using Safari for pop-ups and applications that open web links while not changing the default browser. <!----></span><br><br>- Alternatively they can unset Chromium based browser as the default browser by switching to Safari as the default browser as described here: <span class="line"><!---->- Alternatively they can unset Chromium based browser as the default browser by switching to Safari as the default browser as described here: <!----></span>https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac"><!---->https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/make-safari-your-default-web-browser-ibrwa008/mac<!----></a><br><br>I hope for this feature to be implemented soon so we all can enjoy the conveniences, extensibility and the user experience provided by Chromium browsers.<span class="line"><!---->I hope for this feature to be implemented soon so we all can enjoy the conveniences, extensibility and the user experience provided by Chromium browsers.<!----></span><br><br>--- <span class="line"><!---->--- <!----></span><br><br>Further on this, Chromium based browsers can also be credential providers to macOS, which means users are free to make the choice on where to store their passwords.<span class="line"><!---->Further on this, Chromium based browsers can also be credential providers to macOS, which means users are free to make the choice on where to store their passwords.<!----></span><br><br>Such an integration will allow Chromium browser credential stores to be used within the macOS system including Safari. This might also allow users to make the choice to move to a different credentials ecosystem in the emergence of a better alternative, which can be possibly provided through Chromium. Such ability to migrate would also drive up the demand for Chromium OS based devices as currently this acts as a major barrier for switching.<span class="line"><!---->Such an integration will allow Chromium browser credential stores to be used within the macOS system including Safari. This might also allow users to make the choice to move to a different credentials ecosystem in the emergence of a better alternative, which can be possibly provided through Chromium. Such ability to migrate would also drive up the demand for Chromium OS based devices as currently this acts as a major barrier for switching.<!----></span><br><br>https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices"><!---->https://developer.apple.com/documentation/authenticationservices<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

        <div>

        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Aug 23, 2022, 3:53 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c71">Comment 71<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Aug 23, 2022, 3:53 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        tl;dr: +1, ★'ed<span class="line"><!---->tl;dr: +1, ★'ed<!----></span><br><br>Having used an iPhone for a while, I used the native Keychain feature on it and was able to use Chrome on Windows/iPhone due to the fact that Windows has a chrome extension so that iCloud Keychain can work with it, and the fact that Chrome on iOS works with the native Keychain. After switching from Windows to MacOS, I was surprised that Chrome doesn't work with iCloud Keychain. The fact it doesn't is a very large reason I don't use Chrome as my main browser; I only use it for one website (which doesn't currently work on Safari because it's in a beta version). If this functionality was added, I could easily see myself switching to Chrome/Chromium based browsers again, or at least using one interchangeably with Safari.<span class="line"><!---->Having used an iPhone for a while, I used the native Keychain feature on it and was able to use Chrome on Windows/iPhone due to the fact that Windows has a chrome extension so that iCloud Keychain can work with it, and the fact that Chrome on iOS works with the native Keychain. After switching from Windows to MacOS, I was surprised that Chrome doesn't work with iCloud Keychain. The fact it doesn't is a very large reason I don't use Chrome as my main browser; I only use it for one website (which doesn't currently work on Safari because it's in a beta version). If this functionality was added, I could easily see myself switching to Chrome/Chromium based browsers again, or at least using one interchangeably with Safari.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>
    
      
    <mr-comment headinglevel="2"></mr-comment>
      
      
      
        
          Comment 72<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1170065#c72">Comment 72<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      vitor...@gmail.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/441183473" title="vitor...@gmail.com"><!---->vitor...@gmail.com<!----></a>
      vitor...@gmail.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->vitor...@gmail.com<!----></span>

        +1 and starred.<span class="line"><!---->+1 and starred.<!----></span><br><br>This is my biggest gripe with Chromium-based browsers. I cannot fathom how this feature has not yet been considered - it's a huge usability step-up for macOS users who either store their passwords in iCloud Keychain or a password manager like Strongbox and so many third party platforms have integrated the macOS password autofill at this point. I really hope this is picked up soon.<span class="line"><!---->This is my biggest gripe with Chromium-based browsers. I cannot fathom how this feature has not yet been considered - it's a huge usability step-up for macOS users who either store their passwords in iCloud Keychain or a password manager like Strongbox and so many third party platforms have integrated the macOS password autofill at this point. I really hope this is picked up soon.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
